garden.name: JC's Backyard
garden.tagline: Inspiring others to grow their own food and engage in their community by sharing food and knowledge
garden.description: A community-focused garden dedicated to educating people on how food is grown, fostering sustainable practices, and building connections through shared knowledge and fresh produce.
garden.mission: To inspire and empower our community to grow their own food, share resources, and create a more sustainable, connected neighborhood.

hours.public: Open to visitors: Saturday 9 AM - 1 PM, Sunday 10 AM - 2 PM
hours.volunteer: Volunteer days: Every Wednesday 6 PM - 8 PM and Saturday 8 AM - 12 PM

theme.name: Rustic and Earthy
theme.description: A warm, welcoming atmosphere that connects visitors to the earth and community

programs.name: Growing Guides Workshops
programs.description: Learn the fundamentals of growing vegetables, fruits, and herbs through hands-on workshops

programs.name: Community Garden Days
programs.description: Join us for shared work days where we maintain the garden together and share harvests

programs.name: Seed Sharing Library
programs.description: Borrow seeds to start your own garden and contribute seeds back for others

programs.name: School Visits
programs.description: Educational tours and activities for school groups to learn about sustainable food production

programs.name: Composting Demonstrations
programs.description: Learn how to create nutrient-rich soil through composting

inspiration.notes: A large, well-established organization that serves as inspiration for community impact and educational programming

garden.avoid: Nothing - open to all creative approaches
garden.interactivePreferences: Clean, neat, a bit modern - user-friendly interfaces that enhance the educational experience

vegetables.name: Tomatoes
tips: Start seeds indoors 6-8 weeks before last frost
Transplant after danger of frost has passed
Provide consistent watering at the base (avoid leaves)
Use stakes or cages for support
Harvest when fully colored but still firm
commonMistakes: Planting too early (cold soil stunts growth)

vegetables.name: Leafy Greens (Lettuce, Spinach, Kale)
vegetables.season: Early Spring - Late Fall (with shade in summer)
tips: Can be grown in partial shade during hot months
Succession plant every 2-3 weeks for continuous harvest
Harvest outer leaves first to allow center to keep growing
Prefer cooler temperatures for best flavor
commonMistakes: Planting in full sun during summer heat
Waiting too long to harvest (becomes bitter)
Not thinning seedlings (results in small, weak plants)

vegetables.name: Peppers
tips: Start seeds indoors 8-10 weeks before last frost
Peppers love heat - wait for soil to warm up
Use mulch to retain moisture and warmth
Fertilize lightly when flowers appear
commonMistakes: Planting too early in cold soil

herbs.name: Basil
tips: Pinch flowers to encourage leaf growth
Harvest from the top to promote bushiness
Grows well in containers
Water at base, keep leaves dry

herbs.name: Mint
tips: Best grown in containers (spreads aggressively)
Prefers partial shade in hot climates
Harvest regularly to encourage new growth
Great for beginners - very hardy
commonMistakes: Planting directly in ground without containment

fruits.name: Strawberries
tips: Plant in early spring or late fall
Mulch around plants to keep berries clean
Provide good drainage
Remove runners in first year for better fruit production
commonMistakes: Planting too deep (crown should be at soil level)
Not providing enough water during fruit development

topics.name: Composting Basics
topics.description: Transform kitchen scraps and yard waste into nutrient-rich compost. Mix brown materials (leaves, paper) with green materials (food scraps, grass) in a 3:1 ratio. Turn regularly and keep moist.

topics.name: Soil Testing
topics.description: Test your soil pH and nutrients annually. Most vegetables prefer slightly acidic soil (pH 6.0-7.0). Amend based on test results.

topics.name: Mulching
topics.description: Apply organic mulch (straw, leaves, wood chips) to retain moisture, suppress weeds, and gradually improve soil as it decomposes.

spring: Start seeds indoors for warm-season crops
Plant cool-season crops as soon as soil is workable
Set up trellises and supports early
summer: Water early morning to reduce evaporation
fall: Plant cool-season crops for fall harvest

blogPosts.excerpt: New to gardening? Start here with our beginner-friendly guide to growing your own food.
